repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Fiscal and Administrative Reform
            Special Sector Adjustment Program Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is rated as satisfactory
            while project sustainability is rated as likely. Both World
            Bank and Borrower performances are assessed as satisfactory.
            The lessons learned repeat wisdom common to previous
            adjustment programs. Borrower commitment and ownership is
            essential. A focus on outcome and performance is critical. A
            sound banking system is at the center of a successful
            adjustment program. Monetary policy can play a central role
            but cannot substitute for sound fiscal policy. Cutting
            investment expenditures during fiscal adjustment comes with
            a heavy price. The Bank tends to underestimate the
            difficulty of political agreements without which reforms
            cannot happen and remain in place. Bank preparedness for
            assisting countries with adjustment lending depends
            critically on its conducting prior economic and sector work.

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Fiscal and Administrative Reform
            Special Sector Adjustment Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Fiscal and Administrative Reform
            Special Sector Adjustment Loan Project, will support the
            Government of Brazil's program to improve, fiscal
            performance in general, and, the fiscal performance of the
            states in particular, with an emphasis on administrative
            reform to reduce personnel costs, and increase efficiency.
            Fiscal performance will be improved, mainly by reducing the
            burden of the federal, state, and municipal
            government's wage bill, including that in the Federal
            District. The Fiscal Stability Plan will be introduced, to
            be initiated shortly, and, laws regulating Amendments to the
            Constitution related to the Administrative Reform will be
            implemented. The state's debts will be re-financed, and
            a states facility support will be established to undertake
            administrative reforms. While the benefits call for an
            increased overall public sector balance, resulting from
            reductions in the level of state personnel expenditures, and
            reduced real interest rates from improved fiscal
            performance, it is suggested that risks may occur due to
            higher interest rates on the public debt, and/or domestic
            pressures for additional expenditures, coupled with the
            possibility of recession, preventing a smooth transition of
            dismissed public employees, to private employment. These
            risks are mitigated by the Government's policy
            performance record, and the ongoing economic recovery.
